abstract.p: Erica Choi letter on report (Sept 27) that increase in affordability of data base technology has broadened access to prescription information about millions of Americans who use electronic cards to fill prescriptions; expresses concern that confidentiality of doctor-patient relationship is in jeopardy

block.p: The increase in the affordability of data base technology has broadened access to prescription information on the millions of Americans who use electronic cards to fill prescriptions (column, Sept. 27). Although benefit managers have helped to control the rising cost of prescription drugs by steering doctors to use lower-cost drugs, it is still unclear what else is done with patient information.

The increase in the affordability of data base technology has broadened access to prescription information on the millions of Americans who use electronic cards to fill prescriptions (column, Sept. 27). Although benefit managers have helped to control the rising cost of prescription drugs by steering doctors to use lower-cost drugs, it is still unclear what else is done with patient information.

Until there is strict legislation insuring that those who abuse their access to medical information will be penalized, the message to the patient is that the confidentiality of the doctor-patient relationship is in jeopardy.
